title: Mentor Program for New Players @Riot
body:
This may have been done before, but why not start an in-client function that pairs a new player with an experienced player upon request? A lot of people get satisfaction from teaching new players, and this could ease the new player experience a lot.

Can a Rioter comment on why this has not already been done? I'm sure it's been tossed around in a discussion before.

replies.body:
>Can a Rioter comment on why this has not already been done? I'm sure it's been tossed around in a discussion before.

No rioter is required, because the reason is obvious:

#ABUSING THE SYSTEM.

You may think of this place as a nice fantasy land, where people are itching to help each other out.
Well, here are news for you: You are wrong. Most actual human bings are selfish, driven by greed, avarice and ego, and unwilling to do anything for a stranger if there is nothing in it for them.

So, you would have to hand out rewards, otherwise the system would starve to death.

Rewards for things done by anonymous persons on the internet ALWAYS means: **Clever Bastards will invent ways to abuse the system to reap a maximum of rewards, with a minimum of, or no effort being put in.**

_Just an example how bad this can get: In the ~~good~~ old says when the ~~great~~ sh\*t tribunal was still in place, riot used to give IP for participating, IF your verdict was the same as that of a majority on a given case. So, what happened? People wen't "fk it, I want IP!", and voted guilty ON EVERY SINGLE CASE, because there was statistically a higher chance of cases being punished than not. That lead to a metric sh\*tton of punished people who had literally done nothing wrong, and forced Riot to shut its ~~nice~~ garbage system of handing out IP-for-"justice" down._

Now, could you design the system in a way to prevent that? Yes, you could. With a huge pile of ressources, and constant supervising on the part of Riot invested into it. And at that point, the cost simply outweigh the basically non-existent benefit.

---

Also, if new players want to learn the ropes, there are PETABYTE of instructional vids and written guides out there.

If there is a case opposite of rose tinted glasses, this is one of them.

There's nothing I can really do since you are so convinced you are right based on evidence that would be thrown out on face value in any journal. But I'll do this for fun since I'm a stats guy.

You don't get to pick and choose statistics you like or dislike unless you have a methodological quality reason.

The fact of the matter is that Tribunal players were primarily motivated by goodwill. Of the minority that was motivated by IP, their accuracy was significantly lower. Was it skewed to Type I or Type II error? It doesn't say. It makes sense that people on the Forums would say 'spam punish' because of the self-selection of activeness, but what of the people who didn't post on the forums and were still in it for the IP? They may have a different distribution of error. This is something untestable except by Riot, however, so arguing this point in meaningless.

Also, youtube, reddit, gameplay, whatever. They're all self-selected samples, which means they are shit for representing the population. At best, they are simply some ideas of where to look for some opinion polling, but I'm pretty sure Riot knew that Dynamic queue was unpopular.

But anyway:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/XvqbAgrF-letos-talk-about-dynamic-queues-and-ranked-play


> When we polled a random set of players across all of League of Legends the specific question: “I like that you are allowed to queue with any number of people to play ranked”, about 55% of players agreed, 20% were neutral, and 25% disagreed. We’re not saying this to sway opinions either way--it tells us the system is both polarizing, and broadly desired. We’ll check in on this statistic again next week.


Now move down to here: http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/competitive/riot-pls-ranked-pls-2017-season-ranked-changes
> 
> Anyone who followed our ranked changes this year is now probably thinking "so what changed?" For months, we resisted calls to re-release Solo/Duo Queue alongside Dynamic Queue because we believed queue health for both queues would suffer. We also thought we could improve Dynamic Queue enough to satisfy those who feel left out by its design—specifically, those players who really hate playing against premades (or who think premades destroy the integrity of the ranked ladder).
> But over the course of the 2016 season, we developed matchmaking and design improvements to Dynamic Queue that have increased our confidence in our ability to support two ranked queues. So now we want to try it out.
> Ultimately, there are fundamental, irreconcilable differences between Flex and Solo/Duo Queue beyond their varying rules on premades. Our hope is both queues will thrive by leveraging those differences to attract different types of players.

So here is the picture that is being painted:

1. More people enjoyed dynamic queue, but more people who dislike dynamic queue dislike it very strongly than people who like dynamic queue like it strongly
2. There are regional differences in population of playerbase; the US is not how every region works and dynamic queue was designed to be a one-size fits all
3. After a year of committing to dynamic queue only, Riot still couldn't make it accomplish the goals it set out despite numerous changes, and since it was polarizing they decided to cut their losses and revert back to Season 5.

Significant deviation from this explanation necessitates the claim that Riot is flat out lying. Do you have a third party source that did its own research and came to a different conclusion than Riot? Because if you don't, you are talking out of your ass.

Even forgetting all these things, _(which in itself would make journal throw a statistic back to the author immediately)_, the question asked didn't even test the hypothesis it was trying to support.

I wonder, how many player would have clicked "I agree", had they asked:

I am absolutely aware that I am using anecdotal evidence here. Yes, I used the term "unversally hated", which I shouldn't do when I don't have hard statistical data. I can only say that from all the reactions I saw as an avid solo player, active community member and in touch with whats going on in the professional scene, I did see far more people hating the system, than people enjoying the system, and no arguments as to why the system was supposedly making things better.

Oh that's fine. I full admit to being a bull in a china closet who would fuck up any running experiment simply by being in a 5 mile radius. But I know that so long as you guy scientists don't know what an F-test is and how/when you can/can't apply it, you need me for science more than a man needs a woman for procreation. 

Which is why I ~~show~~ give 'very' serious thought to when scientists beg me to tell them whether they should use a T or a Z test for difference in means. I sit very still with my eyes closed and ~~pretend to~~ think very hard about the answer. It feels like being R. R. Martin and writing GoT.

But onto the substance.

A company will not lie about its statistics in this age because of people like you and me will question and propagate suspicion, which will damage credibility in he future. No, if a company wants to suppress bad publicity, it will simply cut the chord while the research is being done and burn the documents. [We also have a means of looking at systemic bias in publication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funnel_plot), so even this method is not foolproof.

That's not a perfect or professionally satisfactory defense, but it's enough for me to take it with a grain of salt instead of just dismissing it altogether. I mean, simply being published by PEW doesn't defacto mean your methodology is sound, but it's good enough to take the statistics at face value with a grain of salt.

And finally, being the statistician I am, I delineate between gut feelings and reality. If you (or me or anyone) is making a definitive statement about reality, that equates to a statement grounded in statistical evidence. This is why I give people shit when they make a very serious claim about reality and then support it with anecdotes. I'm more open to people presenting their experience as anecdote from the get go. Anecdotes are not useless, just not representative. This applies in even my day-to-day life and conversations with laypeople.

I do like the idea behind it, but you can already do that by playing the game. Let's say you play a game of league, see someone on your team or the enemy's who carried hard and send request them. Ask the player if he/she can mentor you and help you. I mean, there are people on the board who have offered to teach/mentor another player. I don't see a need for Riot Games to use up time and resources to make a program that anyone can relatively already do.

New players often don't know where to look. The end game lobby isn't an effective place to seek mentoring. Ever get trashed, and you're immediately like, "I gotta add that guy and ask for him to be my Master Roshi." It doesn't work at the level of play that new players are at.

I would like to do it, but asides from abuse by  some people, how would you balance it? This is also a reason some surfs exist. They make a new account to help level and teach a friend the game. Would the program be designated to a specific map? Level cap?

This is purely hypothetical and for example. Any player who has been punished by the automatic feedback system is automatically rejected from the program. Players sign up through a website, similar to how we gain access to PBE. Players are matched based on familiarity and skill level with MOBAs.

So, we would be on another serve like how PBE is or just using that as a sign up example? Matching based on familiarity would be problematic I believe. For the same reason as people who smurf to bully newbies. Could make an account and slick the new to MOBA and then cause chaos that way. You wouldn't be able to just ban people like that due to some people adapting to games very easily and dominating quickly. The only way I can see something like this working is if you forced it to be either a bot game, or a custom (maybe sandbox when it comes out).

It's as an example.

It's possible you could aggressively whitelist players that would be acceptable mentors. People always bring me fresh out of the box players who have no idea what they're doing. If I'm busy, I introduce them to my group of friends (who are also coaches) and they always have someone to be a resource. I'm not sure why this would be that much harder.
